Package net.peierls.puzzle

A framework for describing and solving puzzles that can be characterized as a problem of finding a sequence of transitions (or moves) from an initial state to a solution state.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    PuzzleSolver<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    Interface for algorithms that search for solutions to a puzzles of the parameterized type.
    PuzzleState<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    A representation of the state of a puzzle that involves finding a sequence of moves from an initial state to a solution state.
    PuzzleStateFilter<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    A container for states that offers only an approximate containment test, no removal, and no iteration.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    BfsPuzzleSolver<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    Breadth-first-search puzzle solver.
    BloomPuzzleStateFilter<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    An implementation of PuzzleStateFilter with approximate containment that uses a BloomFilter internally.
    DfsPuzzleSolver<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    Depth-first-search puzzle solver.
    ExactPuzzleStateFilter<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    An implementation of PuzzleStateFilter with exact containment.
    FilteredPuzzleSolver<T extends PuzzleState<T>>
    Abstract base for puzzle solvers that use a PuzzleStateFilter to keep track (possibility only approximately) of which states have been seen during the search for a solution.

Package net.peierls.puzzle Description

A framework for describing and solving puzzles that can be characterized as a problem of finding a sequence of transitions (or moves) from an initial state to a solution state.

The primary abstraction is PuzzleState, which defines a successors function and test for whether a state represents a solution. There is no separate puzzle type, because an initial puzzle state instance essentially defines a puzzle: Find a sequence of states starting with the initial state and ending with a solution state with each element of the sequence other than first being a successor of the previous element of the sequence.

To define a new kind of puzzle, implement the PuzzleState methods isSolution, successors, and predecessor, and optionally any of the other methods.

The predecessor method should be defined for states that are produced by s0.successors() to be s0, otherwise it should be empty (initial states have no predecessor). It is also acceptable to define predecessor as always empty, in which case solution lists produced by FilteredPuzzleSolver will contain only the solution state, which might be acceptable if the solution state itself contains all the relevant information.

States must be usable as map keys, so override equals and hashCode properly. Do not include a reference to a predecessor in the implementation of these methods; a state might be reachable in two different ways, but we do not in general want approximate containment tests to return false negatives from two otherwise equal states comparing unequal due to different predecessors.

The initialized method may be implemented to avoid unnecessary computation on states that might have already been seen.

To define a new general-purpose solver, extend FilteredPuzzleSolver by implementing solutionState. Use filterState before searching from any state returned by the state.successors() method.

Two concrete implementations of FilteredPuzzleSolver are provided, DfsPuzzleSolver and BfsPuzzleSolver, correspondingly using depth-first and breadth-first search.

General-purpose solvers should allow users to provide a PuzzleStateFilter supplier.
